Your first assumption is what I'm trying to do.  All I want to do is get
th=
e file path to the ARC file that the current CrawlURI was written to
so tha=
t I can go back later, open the ARC for that URI and parse the
contents of =
the page.  I'll take a look at the ARCWriter to see if I can
make that happ=
en then.  Thanks!

Andrew
--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Michael S=
tack <stack@...> wrote:
>
> Andrew Serff wrote:
> >
> > I want to have a po=
st processor update my own database with the
> > location of the ARC file t=
hat was written for the current crawl
(i.e.
> > for each URI). Is there a w=
ay to determine this location?
> >
>
>
>
>
> Are you asking if you can inse=
rt a processor into the crawler at the
> 'postprocessor' stage to insert th=
e ARC file name a particular
download
> was written to out to a remote data=
base?  If so, the answer is no. 
The
> necessary information is not availab=
le at the postprocessor stage, not
> without changing the ARCWriter so it a=
dds the name of the current ARC
> file to the CrawlURI object so this is in=
fo is available later in the
> processing chain.
>
> Or are you asking abou=
t post-processing ARCs after a crawl is done to
> load a database table wit=
h a key of URI and a value of the name of the
> ARC file that URI was writt=
en too?  If you are asking the latter, this
> is fairly straight-forward.  =
You would write a program that would read
> all ARCs made by a crawl.  Fore=
ach, you would iterate over its
contents
> and per URI, you would write out=
 to the database your findings.  See
> http://crawler.archive.org/articles/=
developer_manual/arcs.html for
more
> on ARCs, their format and available r=
eaders.
>
> > I also don't know much about the ARCs. Do they contain an ent=
ire
> > site, or just one page and all it's associated files (images, etc).=

> > If it can have multiple pages in it, it might change what I'm doing.
>=
 >
>
>
>
>
> Default configuration writes downloads randomly to one of a sm=
all set
of
> open ARC files.
>
> Best way to answer the above question on w=
hats in an ARC, if the above
> cited link does not answer your question, is=
 to crawl and then look at
> their contents.
> St.Ack
>
>
> >
> > Let me kn=
ow if anyone can help! Thanks!
> > Andrew
> >
